content: I've used the paid version for a couple of years and it's been great, but the recipe process is very much less so. You must enter your recipes into MyNetDiary so it can calculate nutrition, which is expected, but maintaining your recipes is absolutely frustrating. Recipes can't be updated once you've used them (ingredients, amounts, etc.). You must make a copy of the original recipe / make the changes you need / save the new copy / retire the old recipe / and finally rename the new one with the old name. MyNetDiary is pretty good at importing recipes, but you still have to use a separate recipe app to maintain your recipes. You make your changes in the separate app / copy your updated recipes to MyNetDiary under a new name / and then proceed as outlined above. Having to duplicate recipes in a more capable recipe app and then continually transferring them back to MyNetDiary is starting to become a deal breaker. I would love for this app to manage recipes better. Also, there is no formatting capability in the recipe notes field for simple things like bullets, headings, etc (eg. TinyMCE). This app deserves 5 stars; these devs are smart guys and should be able to figure this out. If these problems get resolved I will come back and update this review.
content_nonstop: pay version couple year great recipe process much less must enter recipe mynetdiary calculate nutrition expect maintain recipe absolutely frustrating recipe update ingredient amount etc must copy original recipe change need save new copy retire old recipe finally rename new one old name mynetdiary pretty good import recipe still separate recipe maintain recipe change separate copy update recipe mynetdiary new name proceed outline duplicate recipe capable recipe continually transfer back mynetdiary start become deal breaker would love manage recipe well also formatting capability recipe note field simple thing like bullet heading etc eg tinymce deserve 5 star devs smart guy able figure problem resolve come back update review

content: This app has been INVALUABLE to me when it comes to managing my diabetes. I eat a Low Fat Whole Foods Plant Based diet and the food I buy is mostly all fresh produce which doesn't come with nutrition labels. I can just type it all in Cronometer to find out how many carbs to bolus for. Makes it MUCH easier to stick to a healthy diet. There are so many features that are useful I can't list them all. I would really love to be able to import recipes from my own files though. I don't want to enter recipes until I perfect them to my liking. And a couple more Group Name sections would be nice. Overall this is the best app I have ever used! Edited: Such as Word docs, etc. from files on my computer.

content: I am a new user, started three days ago, so I can't say I've tried every option on the app. . .yet. Logging what I eat has been the only thing that has worked for me in the past to lose weight. (To be honest, it wasn't lost - just on vacation.) Once again I'm giving it a shot. One issue I've had with other trackers is poorly maintained food databases. I've found some issues with Cronometer's data differing from the item's "Nutrition Facts"(NF) too. BUT, the other trackers I used let anyone enter data resulting in many, many duplicate and erroneous entries. Cronometer lets you report the issue and send them a photo of the current package's NF. I did this with a couple of items yesterday evening. This morning I received emails saying that they have reviewed and updated their database. Blew my socks off!! Their responsiveness drove me to purchase a subscription. I love the integration of the app with my Fitbit. My scale integrates with my Fitbit, and Cronometer gets the weight from Fitbit. Cool beans.

content: One of the things I like best about this app is that I can make my own foods. I have a recipe site and make certain items that would not be on the list, for example, White Chicken Chili with Corn. I have another program on my desktop that has nutritional values for ingredients, so it's just a matter of naming the food and inputting the values from my other program. I keep track, I know if I'm about to go over or not. It's nice seeing how I'm doing as far as Carbs, Protein and Fats. Am I on a diet? Yes. But, it doesn't feel that way. I record what I ate and then I can see how much I have left so I know whether I can splurge or not. It's nice that it also records how many calories you burned during the day. Having a fitness tracker that talks to Google Fit which talks to the Virtual Gym makes it even nicer. The only change I would make to the app is for it to show sugar intake as well, but other than that it's a great app.

content: This has been great software for keeping track of what I eat (calories, protein, carbs, and fat), how long I’ve exercised during the week, and my weight. I've been using this for 3.5 weeks now, longer than I've ever used calorie counter software food before. I use a combination of preset foods and custom entries to track what I'm eating. (I weigh most of my food.) I exercise with a watch with a heart monitor so I enter the time and calories burned directly instead of using the preset exercise values. Once you get past the minimal learning curve and have entered any custom foods or meals you eat regularly, entering data only takes a few minutes each day. Does this software have all of the bells and whistles that other calorie tracking software has. No. And that is a good thing. All of the data is my phone, not in the cloud. Food information isn’t be stored in the cloud. I don’t have the option to scan bar codes. My data isn’t being sold. I don’t need to login. I can use use it anywhere and everywhere regardless of my data connection. I love it. The free version is supported via adds that generally aren’t annoying, and I could have kept using it happy, but I purchased the pro version of this app because I want to support developers who don't have in app purchases, don’t collect data, and don't require an app to have access to internet to function.

content: I'm not happy with the latest update of Fat Secret. It used to flawlessly integrate with my Diabetes-M app and made it easy to mark things as "favorite" that I ate all the time. I don't have a need for calorie counting etc in FS because I already have that in the Diabetes-M app which I pay for every year. Now, I can't so much as "star" my favorite almond milk in my other app. It says it has to access my FS account (where my favorites are stored), no problem, I say yes. Goes back to the same screen and I click yes again and it closes out what I've entered and pops back to the main entry screen. I realize this problem is an integration problem but I suspect it has something to do with the new premium feature which allows menu building... and "favorites" must count as part of that. If someone has a fix for this, I'd love to hear it because as it stands now, while I appreciate the use of the calorie etc database, Fat Secret is pretty useless in making my life easier as an adjunct app for controlling my diabetes.
